rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:1
rsbNotes.text: 4:1 altar of bronze. Mentioned also in 1 Kin. 8:64; 2 Kin. 16:14. The bronze altar was the main altar. The large measurements are the dimensions of the base, from which steps went to the altar (Ezek. 43:13–17).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:2
rsbNotes.text: 4:2 sea of cast metal. Solomon’s version of the “basin of bronze” in Moses’ tabernacle (Ex. 30:18). The water of this basin was used for rituals of cleansing (4:6; 1 Kin. 7:23 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:3
rsbNotes.text: 4:3 gourds. Though the Hebrew reads “oxen,” the ornamental border was probably gourds of some kind (cf. 1 Kin. 7:24).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:4
rsbNotes.text: 4:4 twelve oxen. See note 1 Kin. 7:25. The twelve bulls pointed to the four directions of the compass (cf. Num. 2 on the encampment of the tribes; Rev. 21:12–14).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:5
rsbNotes.text: 4:5 3,000 baths. 1 Kin. 7:26 reads “two thousand baths.” These are round numbers and not exact statements of volume.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:9
rsbNotes.text: 4:9 court of the priests and the great court. Both courtyards are mentioned in Kings (1 Kin. 6:36; 7:12). The great court was for the laity.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 4:11–22
rsbNotes.text: 4:11–22 The text follows 1 Kin. 7:40–50 in the description of Hiram’s work.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:1
rsbNotes.text: 5:1 David his father. The historian ties Solomon’s temple directly to David’s preparations (2:3 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:2–7:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:2–7:10 The text closely follows the account of temple dedication in 1 Kin. 8. The report is in four balanced sections: an opening celebration of the transfer of the ark (5:2–6:2); Solomon’s blessing (6:3–11); Solomon’s prayer (6:12–42); and concluding celebrations (7:1–10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:3
rsbNotes.text:
5:3 all the men of Israel. Like David, Solomon received widespread support from Israel (1 Chr. 11:1 note).

seventh month. This was Tishri, when the Feast of Booths was celebrated. Since the temple was completed in the eighth month of Solomon’s eleventh year (1 Kin. 6:38), the ark would have been brought in eleven months later.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:5
rsbNotes.text: 5:5 Levitical priests. Repeated references to priests and Levites in this account indicates that Solomon observed carefully the tabernacle and temple regulations (1 Chr. 6 notes).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:9
rsbNotes.text: 5:9 there to this day. See note 1 Chr. 4:41.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 Nothing . . . except the two tablets. In the tabernacle of Moses’ time the ark also contained Aaron’s staff (Num. 17:10, 11) and the jar of manna (Ex. 16:32–34).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:11–13
rsbNotes.text: 5:11–13 See 1 Kin. 8:10, 11. The books of Chronicles emphasize the use of music in worship (1 Chr. 15:16 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:13
rsbNotes.text: 5:13 he is good . . . forever. A familiar line of descriptive praise honoring God for His enduring goodness and mercy (7:3, 6; Ps. 106:1; 107:1; 136).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 5:13–14
rsbNotes.text: 5:13, 14 cloud . . . glory. God blessed Solomon’s temple with His presence as He had blessed the tabernacle (Ex. 40:34–38). The prophets hoped for God’s glory to return to the temple after the exile in Babylonia (Ezek. 43:1–5; Hag. 2:7–9; Zech. 2:10; 8:3).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 6:1–2
rsbNotes.text: 6:1, 2 Solomon expresses his hope for the permanence of the presence of God in the temple. This was a keen concern for the community seeking to reestablish itself after returning from exile in Babylonia in the sixth century b.c. (5:13, 14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 6:5–10, 20, 32–34, 38
rsbNotes.text: 6:5–10, 20, 32–34, 38 name. See note 1 Chr. 13:6; “ ‘This Is My Name’: God’s Self-disclosure” at Ex. 3:15.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 6:9
rsbNotes.text: 6:9 it is not you who shall build. For the explanation of David’s disqualification, see 1 Chr. 22:6–10 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 6:10
rsbNotes.text: 6:10 fulfilled his promise. See notes 1 Chr. 17:1–15.
